title: 107_hr3054
content: The "True American Heroes Act" allows for Congressional Gold Medals to be awarded to government workers who responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center and perished. The "True American Heroes Act" authorizes the President to present gold medals to officers, emergency workers, and employees of government agencies who responded to the 9/11 attacks. The medals will be struck with emblems symbolizing valor and heroism. The Secretary of the Treasury determines recipients and number of medals for the True American Heroes Act. The President consults with various officials for the presentation ceremony. Additional gold medals may be struck for departments and duty stations. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike gold duplicates of medals for presentation to various officials and departments in New York City, including the Governor, Mayor, and emergency response personnel. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine recipients for medals honoring fallen emergency responders. Duplicates in bronze may be sold to fund a memorial for these individuals. The Congress authorizes the use of the United States Mint at West Point, New York to design and strike medals for fallen emergency responders within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Congress authorizes Congressional Gold Medals for individuals on United Airlines Flight 93 who resisted hijackers and caused the plane to crash. On September 11, 2001, United Airlines Flight 93 was hijacked by terrorists and crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania after passengers resisted the hijackers. On September 11, 2001, United Airlines Flight 93 was hijacked by terrorists and crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania after passengers resisted. The leaders of the resistance demonstrated exceptional bravery and patriotism, potentially saving many lives and important symbols of freedom. Congressional Gold Medals are authorized to be awarded posthumously to passengers or crew members who aided in resisting the hijackers. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike gold medals with suitable emblems for presentation purposes. Duplicates in bronze may also be struck and sold under regulations to cover costs. The Act authorizes the creation of national medals under chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code.
